instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00850: What is 820-00850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR: What is PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR? This is the input that comes from the charger..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07
threads.message:
My reference only: TT9775

Board history: No liquid damage, customer states they charged their phone like the always have done and went to go use the computer the next day and it would not turn on.
USB meter intermittently shows 20v, but most often it is at 5v. 
If rotate/flip the meter around on the same port (closest to the screen), on only one side of the board (<CHIP>U3200</CHIP> side), the meter does not power up, if I flip the meter again, the meter powers up. 
I have replaced <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>, <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>, <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, <RESISTOR>R7016</RESISTOR>, and <RESISTOR>R7015</RESISTOR>.
For <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>: Both are CC1: 0, CC2: 1.4.
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL> is 5.1v
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> is 5.1v
F7000 is 12.26 on both pins.
Not sure where else to go?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07
threads.message:
Check for short around <CHIP>U3500</CHIP> and UB700.

Compare diode mode readings on CC1/2 lines between all ports.

Is the machine recognized in DFU?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07
threads.message:
<CAPACITOR>C3508</CAPACITOR> had a short, replaced it and still stuck at 5v. I also replaced <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> once more since there was scraping around it from me trying to get the underfill up. Wanted to make certain no traces were damaged.
DFU Mode: Not able to get it in to this. Have not tried to force it though.
I did notice <CHIP>U3000</CHIP> had solder balls around it. I tried to reflow this. 
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> I am getting .993v. 

Diode Mode:
<CHIP>U3100</CHIP>: CC1 .585, CC2 .589
<CHIP>U3200</CHIP>: CC1 .596 CC2 .601
UB400: CC1 .592 CC2 .597
UB300: CC1 .590 CC2 .596

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07
threads.message: No short at pins 19/20 of <CHIP>U3500</CHIP> and UB700?
